Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical-Emission Spectrometer for use in Paleoclimatic, Hydrogeologic and Geochemical Studies at SUNY Geneseo
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award funds the acquisition of geochemical instrumentation at SUNY Geneseo which will augment the analytical capabilities of a department with a proven record of success in undergraduate research, thereby enhancing the education of the next generation of geoscientists. Three faculty in the Department of Geological Sciences have well-established, undergraduate-friendly research programs that will immediately benefit from the expanded analytical capabilities. The instrumentation will provide high-resolution chemical analysis of rock, sediment and water samples to support ongoing research, and will enable new collaborative research in areas such as geomorphology, petrology, anthropology, and ecology. The research that will benefit from the acquisition is (1) providing key insight to the magnitude, timing and pace of climate changes during the last glacial-interglacial transition in the western U.S. (2) establishing a detailed characterization of ground and surface water chemistry in a region that is targeted for high-volume hydraulic fracturing of the Marcellus Shale for extraction of natural gas; and (3) establishing the impacts of slag on soil and water chemistry in western New York State and the Adirondack State Park, important agricultural and recreational regions. Research in these areas includes field and laboratory components carried out by faculty and undergraduates, in keeping with the tradition of cultivating critical thinking and problem-based learning in the Department of Geological Sciences. This instrumentation will be incorporated into classes reaching more than 300 students per year.

Specifically, this award funds the acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) to support research in paleoclimatology, hydrogeology, and geochemistry at SUNY Geneseo. For research in paleoclimatology and related fields, the ICP-OES will be used by the Cosmogenic Nuclide Preparation Lab, which prepares samples for measurement of cosmogenic Beryllium-10 inventory of surficial deposits and landforms. For hydrogeologic studies, the ICP-OES will enable new research on water quality in areas of upstate New York targeted for high volume hydraulic fracturing. For geochemical studies, the ICP-OES will be used for measuring the concentrations of metal and rare-earth elements in slag, a byproduct of smelting, and in soils and water in environments affected by the disposal of slag. Additionally, the ICP-OES will augment the analytical capabilities of ongoing research in the Departments of Anthropology, Biology and Chemistry at SUNY Geneseo, and provide opportunities for new research in these departments. Acquisition of the ICP-OES also provides new opportunities for collaborative research between the Department of Geological Sciences and other institutions within and beyond New York State.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported acquisition of major research instrumentation in the Department of Geological Sciences at SUNY Geneseo. The instrument, an inductively coupled plasma optical-emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), was purchased to support research of faculty and undergraduate students in three disciplines, (1) glaciation and climate change in the geologic past, (2) chemistry of solid Earth materials used for smelting, and (3) water chemistry in the watershed of the Genesee River. The ICP-OES supports research in these areas by providing a means of measuring trace concentrations of elements found in water and Earth materials.

Intellectural Merit. Research in the area of glaciation and climate change was significantly augmented by the ICP-OES because it improved a method of geologic dating – cosmogenic exposure dating – of glacial deposits and landforms of the last glaciation (19,000-11,5000 years ago). A key outcome of this research is a chronology of the pace and timing of glacier decay in the western United States at the end of the last glaciation. Reconstructing the pattern of glacier decay during this time interval greatly improves the understanding of temperature and surface water changes in the west during an interval of global-scale warming of the Earth surface. Ultimately, this research will inform predictions of how surface water availability will change under projected warming in the 21st century.

            Research in the area of solid Earth materials used the ICP-OES to understand the environmental impacts of disposing byproducts of smelting. The disposal process involves spreading of the byproducts, known as slag, at the Earth surface and allowing it to decay over time. The research determined the concentrations of potentially hazardous metal elements in slag disposal sites in upstate New York, and in soil water where slag has decayed in recent decades. A key outcome of this research is the finding that some of these metals have accumulated in soils beneath slag disposal sites in the Adirondack Park.  

            Research in the area of water chemistry in the Genesee River basin focused on characterizing river and ground water chemistry in areas targeted for high volume hydraulic fracturing of oil and gas-bearing shales. The ICP-OES is being used to measure concentrations of major elements commonly found in river and ground water as well as minor elements found in fracking fluid. The middle part of the Genesee River watershed is targeted for this study. Establishing a record of water chemistry in this area will help to understand if and how hydraulic fracturing will impact water quality in the future.

Broader Impacts. The Department of Geological Sciences at SUNY Geneseo is known for exceptional undergraduate research experiences for students majoring in geology, geochemistry and geophysics. These degree programs are nationally recognized as highly successful at training the current and the next generation of geoscientists. With historically high enrollments in geoscience degree programs at SUNY Geneseo and worldwide, improving faculty and student research experiences is both necessary and challenging to keep up with the demand for highly trained geoscientists in the U.S. and abroad. The ICP-OES is enabling high level research experiences for undergraduates while addressing important environmental and geological problems through faculty-led research programs.
